user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DeleteAllObjects:
```c
void OS_DeleteAllObjects(void)
{
    uint32 ObjectCount;
    uint32 TryCount;

    /*
     * Note - this is done in a loop because some objects depend on other objects
     * and you will not be able to delete the object until the ref count becomes zero.
     */
    TryCount = 0;
    while (true)
    {
        ObjectCount = 0;
        ++TryCount;

        /* Delete timers and tasks first, as they could be actively using other object types  */
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
        OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TASK, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        /* Then try to delete all other remaining objects of any type */
        OS_ForEachObject(OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);

        if (ObjectCount == 0 || TryCount > 4)
        {
            break;
        }
        OS_TaskDelay(5);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
OS_ForEachObjectOfType(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY, OS_CleanUpObject, &ObjectCount);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in the fragment as written. Passing &ObjectCount to OS_ForEachObjectOfType allows the callee to modify the object pointed to (the count), which is permitted by the rule. A violation would occur if the callee modified the pointer parameter itself (for example, within OS_ForEachObjectOfType or OS_CleanUpObject doing an assignment to the pointer parameter, e.g. void OS_CleanUpObject(uint32 *count){ count = NULL; } ), since assigning to the pointer parameter would break Rule 17.8.
